title: Newtown semi with only an outdoor toilet and needing big repairs set for huge buyer interest
text:
It’s got holes in the roof and a kitchen wall with a gaping crack — but that’s not enough to keep the buyers away from this Newtown semi.

Located at 25 Pine St, the property is also described as “virtually uninhabitable” with it lacking creature comforts like an internal toilet.

Despite needing a bit of TLC, the home is still lived in and has been under the same ownership for 43 years.

MORE: 8 mistakes that first-home buyers make

$350k knockout bid for Sydney dump

Iconic Glebe home of prominent lawyer for sale

CoreLogic records show that the home cost the owner a mere $19,500 in 1976, with that purchase price requiring only a 20 per cent deposit of $3900, compared to $262,000 required for Newtown’s current median sale price of $1.31 million.

LJ Hooker — Newtown agent Chris Akkawi will take the semi to auction on November 23 with no formal price guide in place.

“I’m under strict instructions that the home has to sell at auction no matter what price we get on the day,” he said.

With the first inspection to be held on Saturday, Mr Akkawi expects it to appeal to experienced buyers who are probably investors or builders.

“There is a lot of work required, so this will most likely not be something for a first homebuyer, but you never know,” he said.

Mr Akkawi expects that whoever buys the home will probably look to either knock down the home or vastly remodel it.

“There is a possibility to go up into the roof and add a second storey if a buyer wanted to explore that option,” he said.

The current home is a single level terrace with a traditional bullnose veranda. It has two large bedrooms and a third that could be used as a home office.

There is a living room off the kitchen that has a damaged ceiling, cracks in the walls and scratches on the floors.

The kitchen is probably most in need of a renovation with a massive crack down the entire side of one wall, while the other walls are covered in dirt and the wooden roof needs replacing.

At the rear is a courtyard that also has a storage room and laundry, plus an outdoor toilet. This is the only toilet, with a bathroom inside only having a bath tub and shower.

No. 25 Pine St is the third home to come up for sale on Pine St this year. The property across the street at no. 22 sold in June for $2.75 million, according to CoreLogic.

SIGN UP FOR THE LATEST NSW REAL ESTATE NEWSLETTER
description: Buyers searching for something unusual should look no further than this inner west semi that not only needs a lot of work, but also has no indoor toilet.
